participants.participant: Norbert Platt, Group Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good morning, everyone. We're going to change the schedule a little bit, because I have to and I've got to apologize now, I have got to actually go and see people in London that have flown over from the United States. So I just thought I'll just have a quick introduction and explain and thank Norbert, because I don't think he is going to be willing to be at the next analyst presentation. I had to ask him to please be present today.

And then we'll have like 10 minutes of questions that if you wish to ask me questions, but then I'll go and then Richard and Norbert can stay but Richard can go through the numbers and other explanations.

About six months ago, Norbert came to me and he had been diagnosed with diabetes and his doctor actually said he has got to quit in November. Being a loyal friend that he is, he said that he'll stay through the budget cycle, which obviously is very important in March of next year.

Now I had absolutely no intention of wanting to be the CEO again and I said to Norbert, I gave him a few choice words, because I wanted to retire before him. But now he has succeeded in leaving in March. On the other hand he is staying on and helping us especially with the supply chain management, the whole IT project obviously, his baby, Montblanc and then obviously he stays on as a Director.

Now to bring in a new CEO at this stage, let's say from the outside, for the next two years we would have had to teach the individual what's going on, because if you change companies, things are not that easy, especially we are dealing with Germans, with French, with British, with Chinese, with Americans and groups of culture, different cultures. We have a great number of very capable people heading the Maisons.

Now in a normal situation, their Cartier wouldn't report to anybody else, because it's a major company. Here, we've been friends for many years and it's not reporting as such as a coordinating structure, roughly half of Cartier's business has been watches from the day, from 1975 whether then – but I started with Cartier in 1975, '76. So you know the people.

And so I will be taking over from Norbert but obviously we have Richard, Gary Sage and Johann Rupert, people that will carry on. Norbert will be there and I don't think people must read too much into it. The difference is this time that I am coming last count we had over €1 billion in cash. The last time I came after the prior crisis we had to pay dividends out of borrowings. So this is not an internal this is – in 2003, we had some issues.

Yes, we have problems. Not Richemont, but the world and if you ask me to give you an indication of where we are going, I don't know, because as Alan Quasha says, we've never really known as many intelligent people that whose counsel we value to differ so diametrically. There can be a very good case and cases are being made for further contraction and further joblessness and recessionary – economies in recessionary phases when the various central banks start tightening.

But highly intelligent people can also argue that we could get into a very high inflation scenario. So what we are trying to do is we are not telling the Maisons to budget and to run themselves for a disaster scenario. We are telling look, it could get worse, don't be overly exuberant, but plan for normal growth and we've got the balance sheet to cover your backs. And luckily we have a lot of liquidity not only in the company but crudely put, in the holding companies, so that we can give our colleagues the managerial flexibility not to have to tighten down everything.

And secondly this is very much a desperate different market. The Anglo section countries are very badly – the United States, the consumers are doing the logical thing, they're saving. The UK domestic market is also under stress. But what we've got about 294 stores in China – is that about the number, 296, they have opened two since I have gone to bed so it's 296 stores in China. And there we are seeing good economic growth.

The BRIC countries in general are doing well. It's not doom and gloom but it's caution. And I want to thank my colleagues Norbert, Richard, Gary Sage at the back there and the heads of all the Maisons that in the period we had a 15% decline in sales and with the commensurate, the operating leverage drop in operating profit that our cash position has actually improved substantially. I think Gary you showed us the magical €1 billion few days ago. Now this is without the cash of BAT coming in so I want to really recommend all of our colleagues and say thank you very much.

Now, please do not ask me what the Christmas sales are going to be and please don't ask me what we're going to buy. I've no idea what the Christmas sales are going to be. What I do know is that there has been a serious destocking, especially in the United States, but still we suspect there is not too many watches in the market.

We were less hit than some of our competitors, if you recall about a year or two ago, I said I suspect that we will be saved by our lack of capacity. Well, that's actually happened. We didn't actually have enough capacity to flood the market. So hopefully, for the whole US economy we'll see a pick-up because the inventories are very low in the whole of the US system. The people have managed to get their working capital under control. Let's just hope that there is some uptick.

I think finally I just like to thank Norbert for the unbelievable job he has done. When he came here, we had no supply chain management to speak of, we did but we didn't have visibility and not only that, the company has grown dramatically. I am sorry that he is leaving temporarily if I can put it well, he is leaving in March. I suppose he'll be less here but I'm not sure all the Montblanc people are going to enjoy his retirement, because I'm bloody sure he is going to be giving them hell in Hamburg. Thanks, Norbert.

Even though it's only in March, and I'm very glad that you're going to still stay to help us through the budget cycle. Any questions, I'll gladly take sitting down and I've got about 15 minutes. So it's the wrong way around, but if you have questions you'd like to ask them now, I hope I'm not going to contradict what Richard has got to say later on.

Thomas Chauvet, Citigroup. I've got questions on the group strategy for you, Mr. Rupert. If I remember correctly at the time of the annual results in May, you made two important statements. One, you took a rather pessimistic view of future luxury demand in Western Europe, and – sorry?
Of future.

Future luxury demand in Western Europe, and two, you suggested that Richemont might need to change its product offering and maybe the pricing architecture to change – to address changing consumer behavior. Could you update us on these two points and what measures do you intend to take to address these issues?

Thank you. The first one was not an indefinite change in consumer behavior in Europe. It was more that our customers worldwide would not – those with money would rather, would try to be more discreet in spending and we have seen that. It's across the board. It's not only the days of bling may be over for a very long time. However, they will buy fine handcrafted artisanal products and we've seen a continuance in demand.

Secondly, whilst European – should I say inhabitants and citizens may spend slightly less. We have seen traveler, increase in the obvious Chinese travelers coming into Europe. In terms of more welcome products, I think in the next week or two you'll see Cartier coming out with a beautiful Must range and to give you an idea at one of the central product committee meetings one of the designers said to my son, at last now I can afford to buy something that I've designed. So I think it's going to hit a sweet spot. It's – the products are beautiful, but the pricing will be more accessible. And I think the launch started yesterday, was it? The launch started yesterday. There is some, sorry, Sophie?
I think it was the 10th of November.

10th of November, sorry. And I think it will also help work the traffic through the source. So I'd like to comment now for Maisons team for the speed with which they've reacted and the quality of design and product. Any other questions? Antoine?

I can't resist it with the pile of cash building up. How do you look at the payout going forward, the dividend payout? We've had almost a Calvinistic approach to the payout in the previous year. Should we expect now that the cash pile is a little bit higher, a higher payout, should we expect a stable payout? Do you look at the payout as the key metric, how do you look at the dividend policy for the current year? Thank you.

You know, Antoine, you have been around here a long time, not to ask a dumb question like that, okay? Now three or four years ago I said we will try and grow it by about 14, 15% a year, but we will increase the dividends. A Richemont shareholder this year wasn't Calvinistic. It was an increase in the types of dividend paid to the shareholder, you take BAT, take Richemont together. And we look at the sustainability of the earnings.

And in good times our dividend payout ratio, the coverage may be higher but in bad times it may be less. In other words, our coverage may be lower, but right now without having a strong balance sheet Norbert and Richard and Gary and Beck and I would be very loathe to tell our colleagues go ahead and plan for it because what happens if the working capital goes up and we get it on a rebound. I don't want to get into a situation where I've got to ask banks to bail me out.

They may not even be there to bail me out if things really get bad. So I'd like to think if you speak to my colleague, Georges Kern is coming next week but we saw George this week and he said to me after a very long discussion especially at lunch, what must I do, how can I plan if we don't know where it's going. And I said, George, plan according to your plan. Plan according to – I'm not going to tell you what, we'll cover your back.

So this is a way of covering our colleagues' backs, if they are wrong, and we look at it that way rather than a cash pile, and trust me, I have been in a situation where we didn't have a cash pile. And now, this situation I prefer our situation at this stage. And one of the big bugs there is that I've got everybody blames greedy investment bankers. This is nonsense. Everybody is to blame.

The accountants who took reserves away from investors and bankers. I ran a bank, we had – our rule was we have enough hidden reserves the income upon which we can pay the next year's salaries, fixed costs. So we didn't have to do business. Things were bad. We weren't forced to do business. So out came the new rules, everything brought on balance sheet. Then, activist shareholders arrive and say you've got a lazy balance sheet, buy your own shares back and give us dividends.

Luckily, we had enough control over the situation that we didn't have to do it, but a lot of friends, we said come to that. And those famous last words, if you need the capital, we'll give it to you. Yes, right, okay. So people bought their shares back at the top of the market and they're in trouble.

Fund managers were put under inordinate pressure, by pension fund trustees chasing IOU. So I mean I can go on and on and on. This thing was not just, it was endemic to society, but part of it was this lazy balance sheet nonsense. I remember a time when I was involved with some German automobile companies, I remember a time where they had enough cash to set out at least one year, one five-year cycle. Those are the good synergies in the '80s, they had enough hidden reserves to set out one big downturn, a five-year cycle. I'm not sure whether any perhaps Toyota, but we've changed the pressure on management, changed behavior, so that management and corporates are more vulnerable. We're not going to fall into that trap, it's not burning a hole in our pocket. Our shareholders can expect higher dividends as a combined situation than last year and we try to run the business that way. Any other questions? Yes, sir?

Luca Solca from Sanford Bernstein. I was just wondering if you see your pricing strategy medium term and if you anticipate the high-end demand to sustain in the face of higher tax rates that we are seeing coming up in the West. I remember that you were mentioning last time high-end Jewellery was actually sustaining much better than the rest of the business, and if you still see this going forward? And how you reconcile aspirational consumer demand and the fact that you're moving towards successful price points? Is that a temporary measure or do you see this as a strategic development for the company?

They are two, three very good questions. Obviously, if the tax rate goes up it will affect and I do suspect that it will go up. But on the other hand I lived in New York in the 70s when we had to have the municipal assistance cooperation, because nobody wanted to buy the bonds, remember Alan and I worked at Lazards and Felix to form the big neck. I think 10,000 individuals pay what, 80% of the tax in New York City on Manhattan, Alan? Something like 10,000 individuals. Now the Chinese have got a saying, don't scare the donkey that carries the china. You see these folks decide to move to Florida, you've got a fiscal crisis.

Will they increase the taxes? I suspect yes. Will it affect disposable income? Obviously. Will they buy less jewellery? Absolutely. Is the high-end resilient? Not quite. People are postponing purchases. And I have absolutely no problem in working capital even though it's tightly under control but I said to Bernard, do not lose the artisans. You can't replace them. And for clients, this is exactly the best time to buy high jewellery. Not because of pricing necessarily, but because the artisans have got more time, so if you find that Sotheby's and Christie's, the highest prices or the between the war prices, the 1930s, shortcuts, I never figured it out that you pay the most for a pair of furbies that are in the 30s until the gentlemen and ladies from Van Cleef explained to me that's when they did the most resetting because the artisans had time.

So our clients will realize that in terms of investment value and in terms of purity probably now is the best time to buy and to ask for these type pieces. And people are not silly they will figure it out. So I have no problem, I don't want to have a old bunch of steel watches out in the grey market in America, but if they carry on making beautifully bespoke high jewellery, we'll sell it.

The lack of demand is not there in other regions of the world. There is still demand and very good demand. It's really in the United States and Anglo section countries where we've seen that postponement of purchase. Sorry, the third one is the Welcome Jewellery. We try not to call it excess we try to say Welcome Jewellery. I do think it will be a success, yes. And having seen the product especially.

Patrik Schwendimann, Zurcher Kantonalbank. I have two questions if I may. First, regarding communication costs. You have decreased price substantially in H1. I know there was an issue because there was no SIHH but still you have decreased it, I know I mean Cartier has a very strong brand value. So you definitely can afford this. But what's your view on this for looking into the future in terms of communication costs?

We try to look at communication costs as a percentage of sales and even if it looks less, today you get more because the various media companies have also realized that they have to go to come to the pot. My view, I don't think one should play around with communication costs as a cost saving tool. One should consistently support the Maisons. We've never applied pressure on them to do so. If sales pick up, communications costs will pick up obviously.

Maybe if I add one thing. The brands have been obviously cautious in the first half and it's fair to say that you'll probably see in percentage term a rise in the second half which of course contains first of all the launch of the Cartier, the Must which is a major issue and Cartier being the company which is the biggest by size has the biggest budget for communication, but although from the other brands and then of course in the second half you have the SIHH. The Christmas business for us is very important and in the Christmas period I think we want to be seen and our watch brands will spend more money in the second half than in the first. .

I know you've got your job to do which is try and figure out 0.05% and 0.5% and so forth. But I think it's more important to understand the philosophy because hopefully your plan stand by tomorrow, a sale tomorrow and buy the next day because all you making truly wealthy are the traders.

The philosophy is not to mess around with communication costs, but as you correctly pointed out, Cartier has a high low effect. The bigger the brand, the bigger the high low effect. They – if we make sure, we meaning the Cartier management, if they make sure that they have a consistency in communication that when they advertise, there must – there is a high low effect over the watches and vice versa. So Cartier can afford to get less than to get a four – kind of 40, get away with less as a percentage of sales than a pure watch brand.
And secondly, I know that you are a very busy man. So what's your best guess for the time horizon that you want or have to do this year ?
I am a very what man?
Busy, very busy man.

Busy. How long is this recession going to last? No, in the whole seriousness, I like working with my colleagues, it's fun. So I don't consider this a job. It's fun, it's fun working with creative people. I hate to admit what he did was not fun. Beating up people to introduce his SAP is not fun, a German engineer is far better than me at that, okay. And that part wasn't fun and he did it brilliantly.

The fun that we have, product committees sitting with creative people, that's fun. And it's not really – it's not believe me, I've done other things that I've liked a lot less. So how long I couldn't tell you. I would say it's a minimum of two years, but done, then think I think this thing is going to last two years. That's why I'm scared to say how long. The big problem is if you look at the various Maisons that we've got, obviously Bernard is going to get to retirement age some stage. How old is Bernard now, 63, 62, he's turning 63 sooner or later.

Then we're going to have to move somebody there. So you can see that it was just unfortunate. I would have loved to have seen him here for another two years which was our agreement, but I don't know how long it's going to last and it would be totally unfair to take somebody out of a company now at this stage.

We're now all facing issues as we sit here and to bring a new person in our folks, this is a complex business. Just to understand the politics is at least a PhD course in French, German, Italian – yes, in international – don't laugh, I have often said oh that we are air traffic controllers of eagles. You know you've got to know the sky and you've got to know – it's – this is a special business. What it's like, I guess it's like running an investment bank. We've got a lot of talent, self-driven people. And so, it's unfortunate but it's fun, I can't tell you.

If you tell me whether it can be tied to inflation or a recession, if anybody can tell me that because as Alan and I've discussed, I mean you've hit the most incredible arguments both ways. But right now – I've been involved with the Group since about '75 so I know all of the individuals. You don't have to – if somebody calls you, we know how we think. I mean, Norbert and I have now been what 25 years – 22 years, Richard I've known for 30 odd years. We know how we think. You don't have to call somebody and spend half an hour on the phone trying to be nice, neither do they. They call and they say this has happened, you say oh God, will they fix it this way and it's – I don't know how to put it. We don't have to have a honeymoon at this stage. Any other questions? Right.
Mélanie.
Mélanie.

Mélanie Flouquet, JP Morgan. I'm told I have to introduce myself. I have several questions. The main one is really to – this crisis was worse than any on topline that we can see any way from our side. You've done a very good job on EBIT to limit the damage, but on topline it has been quite a lot worse. I wondered what you read this to be – is this a question that is just in deeper that we will recover or is this – are we paying the excesses of the past, was there an element of double? Had we gone too far with price increases which was a bit to Luca's question on Welcome Jewellery?
Yes, yes.

Okay. Can you expand on your view on this? How long will it take to actually recover the heyday sales, can we recover them? Will we get the pricing power that we have had in watches for instance seen the past five years back or do we have to decrease prices there as well?

This is, Melanie, we've discussed it before. The other question brand equity, why are consumers willing to spend more on a BMW or Mercedes than on a Chrysler or a Ford. They have the same amount of steel, glass, leather but there is more perceived value and beauty but very importantly value afterwards. Very interestingly a friend of mine started automobile leasing in the United States, a man called Mike Pascucci years ago, decades ago. I didn't know it but he said to me he could never ever write one lease on a Ford, a Chrysler or a General Motors product.

That's why General Motors had to start GMAC. You see, he said the moment the car left the dealer floor, the price automatically dropped by the embedded costs of and those basically see even less, the medicare. I mean General Motors was an unfunded pension fund debt assembled cost. And the consumer is not stupid, consumer is highly intelligent. They took one look and they said and he could not afford to write a lease. So in whole of his leasing business he never wrote a lease on any of those American cars or European and Japanese cars.

Now when people come in to buy luxury goods products they want to see an investment value. It's not just – and that means you need more artisanal and rarity. The pricing tower will always be there for beautifully made products that people know that their grandchildren consider it an option if they need to. Did the pricing go too far? Yes, absolutely. And I don't think anybody will dispute that fact. Will it come back? Well, if we are tied to inflation you're going to be so glad that you bought that stuff two months or six months ago.

So I really couldn't tell you. That's what I said to Bernard. I said Bernard, keep on going. Please believe me, if inflation picks up, you are going to be seeing people running into your stores, buying high jewellery. It is not only gold. You are going to see it. I don't know, I'm not going to bet on it, but in general, Melanie, you're right. Then you've got to be more efficient.

Our job is to make our wholesale clients make money by giving them better service, we're talking watches now, so their turnover per square meter and square foot is better, then they will have us and we'll continue. It's right that diamond prices are down, but the gold prices are up. So, yes, I don't know where these things are going to end up.

As long as we keep the brand equity pure, you will have pricing power. But I think, Melanie, the key thing is that pricing power is a relative concept. You could have more pricing power than your competitor. You don't have to have absolute pricing power. OPEC's got that. We don't have it. Relative pricing power that when somebody walks in the door to buy that product and that product is what we can try to achieve. And that again works with communication and consistency in communication. In some countries we're going to have to gain market share where the markets are sluggish and in other countries if we gain market share in greatly growing economies we're going to be very happy and luckily a number of our Maisons started early in places like China.

So that not only is the brand awareness there but the desirability is also there. And they are relevant to the consumer. So we're lucky. Sometimes you needed the luck. And we're lucky that we're well positioned in some of the growing markets. Okay, Mélanie, one more.

I have a follow-up, sorry, on the US. There has been statements from the Group, I think from Norbert, notably that the US media has said this quarter that will take quite a while to recover. What is your view on the US consumer in the past you – a while ago you had been very bullish on the structural growth prospect for the luxury goods sector in that market. What's your view now for the medium-term?

I will never bet again – I will never bet against the United States of America. A lot of people have gone bust that way. I happen to agree with Roubini that there is a huge carry trade going on, because it's a one-way bet, borrow in the dollars and go abroad. Obviously it's hitting us. If you look at the – you know the business well enough to know what the exchange rate is doing to us, we've got a weak dollar and a weak yen, not a great scenario. And you know, the Fed is not going to put an orange light between the green light and red light.

They are not – I mean it's not their job to say, whoa, slow down, now we are going to put the red light on. I was in Wall Street and I was a very junior gofer, as they say gofer coffee, gofer tea you know when Mr. Volcker, Paul Volcker, raised the discount rate by 1% in the middle of an IVM issue where we were on the Maison level, and some naïve people said how can he do that, didn't he know that we've got $1 billion issue and I'll never forget, I think it was Felix who said, no, you know as damn well we've got the middle of this issue and he just wanted to show us who is boss. Now that was after this disaster, this Blumenthal era with inflation. Now the Fed is not going to and there was a very interesting article by, I think it was the Chicago Fed, where I said they will act when we don't think they are going to act.

Now one day they do something, that dollar could go the other way and serious disruption could take place with all of these carry trades that are carrying on. I don't know but I don't want to be in a position where all of our shareholders are hurt in the process. So you ask me the United States of America, the United States of America don't have $35 work weeks with bridges that are connected by a viaduct they don't have the concept of viaduct.

They don't take half of May off to go on holiday. They don't have the demography like Japan or for that matter parts of Europe. They are a welcoming country, they allow immigrants, their democratic – demography is better, and they've got a habit of fixing things. Bankrupt, fine, go bankrupt. You go bankrupt in Germany or I mean that's it. You're tainted, goodbye, you – I mean you basically go, you're out.

The society can restructure itself. Is it under stress? Yes. But remember one tiny little thing, their debt is in a commodity that they can price themselves. So ultimately if the dollar depreciates, c'est la vie. I'd be more worried about holding a lot of dollar debts like China. I am just talking as a central banker and I believe the United States will be back quicker than most people think. Is it going to be very painful? Yes. Is it very painful right now? Yes. Are our trade partners suffering? Yes. Yes, yes, yes. I am surprised, Gary and I – we had a discussion yesterday.

I am surprised that we haven't seen more bad debts coming out of the United States which we haven't. I would have thought that we'd have seen a lot of liquidations and a lot of bankrupts by now, we haven't. Will there be structural changes? Yes, but that's the American way. But I brought out that bridges and viaducts and in all of August you've gone and then – I mean at least we used to work in night. Now May has got two viaducts.
In France.
In France.
This is Switzerland.

I know. But we have a big business in France. The competitiveness, that will be back. We may, Melanie, have to rely upon the technological revolution for the next growth in productivity and if it comes it's again going to come out of the United States. Fall out nanotechnology, I don't know, we had a board dinner. The most important thing in the Richemont Group, it's not the board meeting. It's if you missed the board dinner the night before you don't know what's going to happen the next day.

Because that's when all the people voice their opinions and pop their shrimp, decided we are way too pessimistic. So he got up in a very Teutonic way, lectured us on why he believes the future is good and how they will solve the energy problem and how they are beginning to think things are fine. I don't know – you've got to be hopeful that the change in technology was for productivity. Two more questions and that's it.

I'm Lillian from Barclays Capital and I have two questions. We've seen that de-stocking in the US; I was wondering if you could give some color on the wholesale, retailers in Europe? What kind of trends are you seeing in terms of new orders?
And the second question is also on Europe, in terms of demand, who is spending in Europe this year compared to last year, is it the Europeans, is it the Chinese in terms of proportion?
Are you with BarCap?
Yes.
I hope Bob Diamond gives you a big raise and you can start spending with us.
So do I.
No, I think that is probably a better answer, Richard.
Actually, you will see later, my presentation is more detailed.
It's part of the presentation, yes, yes.

If you're going to ask me a question that you suspect might be in the presentation, please. That's why I said I hope I don't say things that he is going to say. Thank you very much. Sorry, but I have to – got to catch a flight.
Good morning to you all. So I've not much to say now, I think that everything has been said. So you may have just some detail and we may start with financial highlights.

Reported sales down by 15% as expected. The only positive factors are the underlying trend has improved monthly ever since April and retail sales has consistently outperformed wholesale. Geographically the only area that continued to show growth albeit to a lower rate was Asia-Pacific. The Americas showed the weakest performance. However, as the result of realistic forecast and a disciplined approach to production management and investments, cash flow from operation rose to €321 million, leading to a substantial net cash of €902 million. Of course as far as operating profit is concerned with lower sales and lower gross margin, the operating profit declined to €390 million.

We are continuing with our action plan detailed last May and I shall briefly review this again later on during the presentation. It's our view that we faced very strong comparatives. Last year most of the growth varied between 14 and 24% at constant rate until September, when the rate of growth declined to single-digit. We hope that this first six months of our financial year that have been fully impacted by the peak of the financial crisis represents the worse of the crisis.

Our sales number reflects the importance of wholesale in our business model given the weight of watches for Richemont. Wholesale is known to amplify trends, both upwards and downwards with a phenomenon of stocking and de-stocking. Wholesale are so large beyond retail, both points will be reviewed later. Swiss Watch exports through September declined by 26% leading to a similar rate of decline year-to-date.

These statistics confirmed that there are no signs of an imminent recovery in the Watch segment and that the lack of visibility regarding demand for Christmas has led retailers to adopt a wait-and-see attitude.

The other important factor is currencies. The yen and US dollar strengthened versus the euro. Overall currencies played in our favor and reported sales were above organic sales, a trend that is likely to reverse in H2 with a weaker US dollar. As to the stronger Swiss franc this negatively impacted our gross margin. It is again this difficult environment that we shall now review the Richemont results starting with sales.

Sales in Western Europe, our biggest region with 32% of Group sales, decreased by 22%, bringing sales back to the September 2007 level. Wholesale greatly underperformed retail. Sales with local continued the decline while sales with third-party nationals not only from Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Asia experienced a slowdown due to the non-repetition of exceptional high-ticket high jewellery sales.

In Russia and the CIS market, wholesale sales were particularly impacted by liquidity issues. Overall sales declined and as a result this market reduced its contribution to 2% of Group sales. Sales through Russian nationals globally are estimated to contribute some 6% of Group sales.

Sales in the Middle East fell by 10% after plus 49 as constant rates last year. This region contributed 6% of Group sales. We estimate that around 10% of Group sales are made with Middle East clientele.

Asia-Pacific remains our second important region after Europe. Its proportion of sales has risen to 32% of Group sales from 26% the year before. After four years of continued strong double-digit growth, sales decreased by a modest 2% at constant rates. Reported sales however increased by 6% and retail sales by 14%.

There were notable differences between main markets and channels. Wholesale sales only leveled off in August, while retail sales turned positive in July consistently between wholesale. Both channel experienced a lower rate of decline month after month confirming that Asia-Pacific is not only the most resilient region but also the first to recover.

Sales in Singapore and Taiwan and to a lesser extent Hong Kong were down while in Korea sales grew by 22% with the return of Japanese tourists due to the appreciation of the yen. In Mainland China sales rose by 3% after plus 30% last year and plus 53% the year before. Mainland China has increased its contribution to Group sales to 8% and ranks number five after Hong Kong, Japan, the US and France.

Now, let's look at the sales by product line at constant currency. All product lines have a similar performance except for leather. That proved to be the most resilient category due to its retail exposure, shorter product lifecycles and more accessible price points.

Sales of leather goods were 11% despite the commendable performance of Chloé and Lancel. Watch sales are down by 20%. The evolution of the sales of watches, our core business has been worse by the wholesale element of the distribution.
Many retailers have opted to massively destock. This decline compares to minus 24% in near term for the Swiss watch exports or CHF500 and above segment over the same period.

Jewellery sales declined by 20%. This is mostly due to non-recurrence of exceptional high ticket high jewellery sales so far. As our jewellery lines were more resilient, Writing instruments remains a difficult market, particularly in the US and Europe. The decline of 22% in other primarily reflects lower sales at our manufacturers of watch components to third parties.

Retail sales represents sales in our directly operated stores. They do not include sales to our franchise stores, which are categorized as wholesale. They declined by 13% at constant rates, 7% at actual rates, more or less harder rate of decline at wholesale.

As a result, the rate – the weight of retails rose to 45% of good sales. The resilience of retail is attributable to the absence of destocking carried out by third parties. All our Maisons are showing much better performances with our retail network. Watch sales in Cartier retail network for instance are down by a low single-digit at constant rates and up in euro terms.

Here is our P&L. Sales decline at 15% in euro terms and 20% at constant rates. The average operating profit decreased to €390 million or 16.4% of sales. The decline was contained, thanks to a lower operating expenses resulting in an operating gearing of 2.6 times.

The gross margin decreased to €1.5 billion in percentage terms. The decline was contained to 250 basis points representing 61.5% of sales. This decline is a result of lower production volume on manufacturing fixed costs and a stronger Swiss franc. These negative points were partially offset by '09/'10 pricing power, higher proportion of retail sales, lower high jewellery sales and translation gains at sales level.

In this negative context, Cartier managed to maintain its gross margin percentage while Van Cleef & Arpels, Alfred Dunhill, Chloe and Lancel increased theirs. The Specialist Watchmakers with a substantial investment in production suffered most.

Net operating expenses declined by 7%. Selling and distribution costs, 56% of the total effects were flat in spite of the extension of the network. This was achieved thanks to a combination of actually first, the slowdown in stores openings, second, lower variable expenses including lower compensation leases and third containment of all – of other costs.

Communication costs declined by 31% to reach 9% of Group sales. The decrease reflects strict control but also better negotiated rates and the timing of the SIHH Watch Salon now taking place in H2. For the full year this ratio will be more in line with the past given the seasonality of our business and the SIHH Salon to be held in January 2010.

All our Maisons exceeded the sales targets. The Jewellery Maison and the Specialist watchmakers generated a contribution margin well above 20%. This performance was partly offset by lower reserves at branded, especially at Montblanc, 12% of sales and at our non-branded watch component manufacturers.

The Jewellery Maisons, Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels reported a decline of – in sales of 14% led to a lower contribution of €349 million. The contribution margin, however, remained strong at 29% of sales. Watch Maison surpassed the sales and profit targets. The limited reduction in profit margin underlines the strong brand equity of Watch Maisons and a successful penetration of gross markets especially for Cartier.

Reported sale of the Specialist watchmakers declined by 17% in euros impacted by less demand, especially, from watch retailers following years of extraordinary growth. The operating contribution declined to €133 million due to a lower sales – a lower gross margin rate linked to under-utilization of manufacturing capacity, a stronger Swiss franc and the integration of Roger Dubuis which is currently loss making. The contribution margin was 20% of sales.

Panerai, IWC, Piaget, Jaeger-LeCoultre, Vacheron Constantin posted contribution margin well above 20%. As for one Montblanc high exposure to the US and Europe 45% of sales as well as to wholesale business has made this more sensitive to the economic slowdown. Reported sales declined by 16% and the operating contribution decreased by 6% to €29 million. As a result the operating contribution margin slightly improved to 12%.

The €118 cash inflow in respect of government bond funds relates to the new accounting treatment of our cash and equivalents. The lower tax payment reflects primarily lower taxable profit. Cartier new store in Ion Orchard in Singapore and Van Cleef & Arpels new store in Milan. After the cash payment of €71 million in ordinary dividends at the end of September '09 and the transfer of €351 million to Reinet in October 2008, Richemont's balance sheet is very sound. Inventory at €2.4 billion is our biggest asset, representing 33% of our total assets followed by cash and short-term government bond funds, 26% and fixed assets, 20%.
